resources.string: All the locations that are featured

This hotel in the heart of Sergiev Posad is located a 5-minute walk from Troitse-Sergiev Lavra. The property was renovated in 2014. Free WiFi is available throughout the entire hotel.
 All rooms at the Posadskiy are air-conditioned and have a flat-screen TV, tea coffee maker, and a private bathroom with a hairdryer and free toiletries. Suites have a spacious seating area with couches and a coffee table.
A continental breakfast is served every morning.
We speak your language!

string.name: hotel_map_link1
string.a: пр. Красной Армии, 171, Сергиев Посад, Московская обл., 141310

resources.string: Located in Sergiyev Posad, 1.2 mi from Trinity-Sergius Lavra, Gosudarev House Hotel complex Imperial Village provides accommodations with a restaurant, free private parking, a bar.

string.name: hotel_2_map_link
string.a: Ulitsa Mitkina, 14/2, Sergiyev Posad, Moscow Oblast, 141302

resources.string:
Located in Sergiyev Posad, Barskiye Polati Hotel offers free WiFi and free private pakring. 
 All rooms are air conditioned and come with a flat-screen TV, fridge and electric kettle. Junior suites feature a seating area. The private bathroom includes free toiletries, slippers and a hairdryer. 
 Guests can dine in local cafes that are within a 7-minute walk from the hotel. 
 Troitse Sergieva Lavra Church is a 5-minute walk away. 
 Barskiye Polati Hotel is 0.9 mi from Sergiyev Posad Train Station and 50 mi from Sheremetyevo International Airport. 
 This is our guests favorite part of Sergiyev Posad, according to independent reviews. 
 Couples in particular like the location – they rated it 9.3 for a two-person trip. 
 We speak your language!

string.name: hotel_3_map_link
string.a: Ulitsa Valovaya, 2, Sergiyev Posad, Moscow Oblast, 141302

resources.string:
The old hotel Lavra is located in a 19th century building in the very center of Sergiev Posad. The hotel is located 50 m from the main attraction of the monastery of the Holy Trinity St. Sergius Lavra.
Free WiFi and free parking are available.
The rooms at the Old Hotel Lavra are decorated in a classic style and equipped with wooden furniture. The windows overlook the Trinity-Sergius Lavra, Red Army Avenue or the courtyard of the hotel.
All rooms are equipped with a refrigerator, kettle, TV and telephone. A hairdryer and toiletries are provided in each room.
There are 2 restaurants - Refectory Chamber and Guest House at the hotel. The restaurants serve local cuisine. The menu includes both lean and light meals. The reception is open 24 hours a day.
There is a bus stop right in front of the hotel with connections to other areas of Sergiev Posad. Sergiev Posad Train Station and Central Bus Station can be reached on foot in 10 minutes, or 2 stops by public transport.
Couples in particular like the location – they rated it 9.9 for a two-person trip.

string.name: hotel_4_map_link
string.a: Prospekt Krasnoy Armii, 133, Sergiyev Posad, Moscow Oblast, 141315

resources.string:
Located in the historical part of Sergiyev Posad, just a 5-minute walk Trinity Sergius Lavra Monastery, Tsentralnaya Hotel features air-conditioned rooms, free Wi-Fi and a free car park. Belyy Pond is 500 m away.
The classic-style rooms offer a fridge, kettle and TV with cable channels. The private bathroom is equipped with a shower and free toiletries.
Continental breakfast is served every day. A number of cafes, bars and restaurants is a short walk away.
Both Sergiyev Posad Train Station and Bus Station are 1 km away. The nearest bus stop is a 5-minute walk away.

The property has a garden, as well as a terrace. The accommodation provides evening entertainment and a concierge service. 
At the hotel, rooms are equipped with a wardrobe and a flat-screen TV. The rooms at Krasnaya Gora Boutique Hotel have air conditioning and a desk. 
A Full English/Irish breakfast is available each morning at the accommodation.

Located in Sergiyev Posad town, this hotel is a 5-minute walk from the Troitse-Sergiyev Monastery. It features air-conditioned rooms and free Wi-Fi. Private parking is offered for free. 
Decorated with elegant furniture, rooms at Imperial Village Hotel come with a TV, fridge and mini-bar. Private bathrooms are fitted with a shower. 
Guests can enjoy Italian, Russian and European cuisine at the on-site restaurant, and relax at the bar. 
Spa center includes a sauna and massage service. 
The nearest bus stop, providing access around the town, is 300 m from Imperial Village Hotel. Sergiyev Posad Train Station is 2.5 mi away.

This hotel lies in the centre of Sergiyev Posad, just a 10-minute walk from the Trinity Lavra of St. Sergius. A 24-hour front desk and a sauna are featured at Aristokrat Hotel. 
The bright, classic-style rooms of the hotel have warm-coloured interiors. Each room includes a TV, a refrigerator and a private bathroom. 
Aristokrat Restaurant overlooks the Lavra and serves European, Asian and Russian cuisine. A variety of drinks, as well as billiards and karaoke, are offered at Aristokrat Bar. 
The Sergiyev Posad Observation Deck is just a 10-minute walk from the hotel. The Kovcheg Theatre and the Toy Museum are only 300 m away.

This hotel is located in the village of Vozdvizhenskoe, 10 km from Sergiyev Posad. Tsar-style interiors, free Wi-Fi and a 24-hour front desk are featured at Peter Palace Hotel. The property features a spa and wellness centre, indoor pool with salt water, hammam and steam room. \nThe elegant rooms of this hotel offer warm decor. Each room features a TV, a refrigerator and a private bathroom. \nPeter Palace Restaurant is decorated with paintings of Tsar Peter the Great and serves Russian and Italian cuisine. Barbecue facilities are located on the terrace. After a meal guests can relax in the comfortable fireplace hall.

resources.string:
Russkie Sezony Парк Отель is spread over 73 hectares of land and is in Peresvet, Moscow region, 15 km from the centre of Serviyev Posad. This property offers a professional hockey rink, skating rink, ski trail and football field, as well as a cinema. Free Wi-Fi access in all areas and free private parking are available. 
The classic-style air-conditioned rooms feature a flat-screen TV with satellite channels. The bathroom comes with free toiletries and a hairdryer. 
Guests can order dishes of Russian and European cuisine in the on-site Arena restaurant, and a further restaurant is available on site. There is also a summer terrace. Bicycle and rollerblades rental is available. 
At Russkiye Sezony Park Hotel Peresvet you will find a 24-hour front desk and 3 swimming pools, one of which is heated all year long. Other facilities include a sauna, fitness centre, ski storage and ski equipment hire. After a day out, you can sing karaoke with friends, play a game in the 4-lane bowling alley or relax in the spa centre and beauty salon. Younger guests will enjoy the children’s playground.

The Gostevaya Izba (Pilgrims Refectory) restaurant and museum of Russian gastronomic heritage is located in the historic building of the Old Monastery Hostelry wine cellar at St Sergius Holy Trinity Lavra. Opened in 2012 the restaurant was established to recreate the Russian households cuisine from the Middle Ages to nowadays. The wooden furniture, waiters’ outfits and folk prints on the walls replicate the authentic items from the Sergiev Posad State History and Arts Museum Reserve. Mantelpieces are tiled with unique ceramic tiles manufactured using the old casts. The Gostevaya Izba (Pilgrims Refectory) has two banquet halls and a small private dining room seating 25, and two spacious patios, which suits a large gathering, a family or a group of friends. Guests are welcome to get acquainted with the Russian culinary traditions in all their variety.

Welcome to the cafe of Buryat cuisine! Buryats are Mongolian people living on the shores of Baikal. Like all the Mongols, they bred cattle. Their lives and traditions have long been dictated by the harsh conditions of the steppe. Serious resource constraints (before the arrival of the Russians, the Buryats were not engaged in the collection and tillage) dictated their own rules of management. Buryat national cuisine is very tasty and varied. The basis of many dishes consumed fresh meat.

The largest and most notable building of the Lavra stands in the center of the monastery. The cathedral was built in 1559-1585, and the Assumption Cathedral of the Moscow Kremlin, which by that time was about a hundred years old, was taken as a model. The result is a huge five-domed temple, with the central dome being gilded, and the other four made in blue with stars. There is almost no decor. Inside, the iconostasis has been preserved, some of the icons in which were made in the 16th century (local row), and almost all the rest - at the end of the 17th century. It is known that, among others, Simon Ushakov worked on the iconostasis, but it is not known whether there is anything of his work there. It is possible that he made all six images on the Royal Doors. The entire cathedral, including the domes, is painted with frescoes. They were made in 1684 in three months by Yaroslavl craftsmen under the direction of Dmitry Plekhanov. Saints Innokenty of Moscow (the first bishop of Kamchatka and Alaska) and Macarius Nevsky are buried in the cathedral. Outside, at the western corner of the cathedral, stands the Dormition storehouse with a chapel (originally 1644, but at the end of the 17th century rebuilt under the Baroque, so it turned out to be a wonderful example of the style). The chapel has the form of a miniature church, with carvings and paintings. On the other hand, also outside, the tomb of the Godunovs is located, where, in particular, Tsar Boris Godunov is buried.

The main temple of the Lavra and its oldest building. The cathedral was built in 1422-23 on the site of a wooden church that stood earlier on this site. It is a four-pillar one-domed temple built of white stone. From the early architecture of the Moscow principality, quite a few buildings have come down to us - in particular, the Trinity Cathedral is noticeably older than the cathedrals of the Moscow Kremlin and a little younger than the churches in Zvenigorod and in the Andronikov monastery in Moscow - and this is certainly one of the best examples of the style. The cathedral is not very large, its height is only 30 m, but the proportions are chosen so well that you dont pay attention to the size. Initially, the cathedral was painted by Andrei Rublev and Daniil Cherny, but their frescoes have not survived, but in the 17th century new ones were painted for the same motives. The iconostasis was created at the beginning of the 15th century (the deesis, festive and prophetic ranks were performed in the workshop of Andrei Rublev) and then supplemented with new icons until the end of the 17th century: in particular, several icons were made by Simon Ushakov. The cathedral houses the tomb of St. Sergius of Radonezh.
Church of the Nativity of John the Baptist

The church was built in the years 1693-1699. It seems that it is rather strangely located, inside the monastery, but very close to the Assumption Gate. Moreover, there is an arch under it, that is, the church was once a gateway. Indeed, once the wall ran to the west than it is now, and later was moved, so that the territory of the lavra increased. The Church of John the Baptist was built on the money of Grigory Stroganov, and it is often ranked among the six surviving Stroganov churches in Russia - the other five are in Solvychegodsk, Ustyuzhna, Usolye and Nizhny Novgorod (two). Like other Stroganov churches, this one has an exceptionally rich exterior decor. The building itself is a quadruple set on a cube, on which, in turn, there are five small domes (they were restored after the 1974 restoration). The iconostasis inside the early 19th century.

The small church between the Assumption and Trinity Cathedrals is the second oldest surviving building of the Lavra. It was built in 1476-1477 by Pskov craftsmen. Pskov architecture is remarkable for its belfries, integrated with the main volumes of churches. Here the builders took as a model the nearby Trinity Cathedral, but added a belfry with bells right above the main volume of the church, and above the belfry they put a single dome (currently blue with stars). This is the oldest structure of this type that has come down to us (the church "like the bells"). The church is brick-built with rich decor. Inside the painting is from 1665, but the iconostasis is relatively new, from the 19th century. Several saints are buried in the church, the most famous of which is Maxim the Greek, the greatest philosopher and theologian of the 16th century.
Church of Zosima and Savvaty Solovetsky

The tent-roofed church, built in 1635-1637, when the monastery was being rebuilt from the destruction of the Time of Troubles. Kelare Alexander, who coordinated the restoration, was himself from the Solovetsky Monastery (founded by Zosima and Savvaty), from which, probably, the dedication of the church comes. This is the only tent-roofed church in the Lavra: it is assumed that the Transfiguration Cathedral of the Solovetsky Monastery was taken as a model. It is decorated with decor, and at that time it was not entirely trivial. From the south and north, simultaneously with the church, two-story Hospital chambers were built, where elderly monks lived. Inside there is an icon of the 17th century depicting Zosima and Savvaty, the iconostasis itself is modern.

The church, connected to the refectory, is one of the largest in the Lavra and is remarkable for its exterior painting that gives the impression of relief, porches with stairs, as well as rich decor, including columns and shells. Sergievskaya church was built in 1686-1692 and is one of the best examples of Naryshkin baroque. It suffered from a fire in 1746, and in 1749, according to the project of the architect Zhukov, an iron roof was made for it, a rather complex engineering structure at that time. Inside, there is also rich decoration of the late 17th century, murals in 1788 by a group of artists under the direction of a certain Yankovsky. The iconostasis of the 17th century (already brought to our time from Moscow), probably with icons by Semyon Spiridonov. The Refectory Chamber adjacent to the church is the largest historical single-domed building in Russia. Next to the refectory there is a small Mikheevskaya church (1734) with an iconostasis from the 18th century.

A very small church from 1746-1753. was built in order to store the carved stone icon of the Smolensk Mother of God. The icon is now in the museum, and a copy is carved on the outer wall of the church, however, the quality is much inferior to the original. The architect of the church is Dmitry Ukhtomsky, one of the most famous Moscow architects of the 18th century. Apparently, this is why the church has a round layout, which is completely uncharacteristic of Russian churches. Inside a 19th century fresco.

The bell tower was built from 1741 to 1770, it was started by the architect Johann Jacob Schumacher, and Dmitry Ukhtomsky was finishing the construction. The height of the bell tower is 88 m, which is higher than the bell tower of Ivan the Great in the Moscow Kremlin, and has four tiers, standing on a cubic base. Several bells are historical (the oldest was cast in 1420), the rest were melted down in the 1930s, and new bells were cast already in the 2000s.

The two-story building of the Tsars palaces with elegant decor of white stone and polychrome tiles occupies the entire northern side of the monastery and was built on the site of the wooden palace of Ivan the Terrible. The polychrome "checkerboard" coloring of its facade echoes the design of the Refectory Church opposite. On the western side of the building, the stucco decoration of 1745-1748 has been preserved, where, among other things, there are images of the battles of Peter I. The interior decoration includes two tiled stoves from the middle of the 17th century, not the most outstanding painting of the vaults was made in the middle of the 18th century. The room is occupied by a church-archaeological study with a collection of books, icons and church utensils.

A lot of interesting things can be found in the vicinity of Sergiev Posad, if you drive a little from the city center. So, for example, three kilometers southeast of the Lavra is the Gethsemane Chernigov skete, which at one time was not inferior to the Lavra in terms of the number of pilgrims. It was founded in 1845-1850, most of the buildings have survived to this day. The architectural dominant is a five-tiered bell tower with two aisles (1895), towering over the district. Cave temples, a chapel, monastic cells and a holy underground spring under the Chernigov Cathedral (1886-1893) attract tourists and pilgrims to this day. Excursions are organized around the skete. The monastic hostel was reopened in 1990.

Before the revolution there was a dacha of a charity house in the village, and the church was built in 1901 as a house by the project of the Moscow architect Ivan Pozdeev. It was built of red bricks and integrated into the brick building of the dacha, which has also been preserved. For a long time, the building was used inappropriately, in particular, it housed a bearing plant, called the "Laboratory of an experimental plant" - an abbreviation for this name and gave the name to the village. Now, there is a boarding school for girls-orphans and a convent inside, but outside the building of the dacha and the church are more interesting than inside.

At the mention of the city of Sergiev Posad (in the past - Zagorsk), the imagination immediately draws temples, churches, sketes, springs, the Trinity-Sergius Lavra ... and the Ilyinsky Church (in the name of the Holy Prophet Elijah), an ancient city temple located on a picturesque a hill near the Kelarsky pond, in the old part of Sergiev Posad, not far from the Trinity-Sergius Lavra.

The Konny Dvor Museum Complex is one of the four branches of the Sergiev Posad Museum-Reserve. It occupies a solid territory of the former monastery stables on the banks of the White Pond, which is at the corner of the Trinity-Sergius Lavra complex. It houses several permanent exhibitions dedicated to the archeology of the region, the history of the monastery, Russian decorative and applied art of the 18-21 centuries and the world of the Russian village, as well as various exhibitions, including the Museum of Russian Matryoshka, a collection of tiles and views of Russian monasteries. And here it is also interesting to just walk around the territory and imagine how the economic life of the Lavra once proceeded during its heyday.

The Sergiev Posad Museum-Reserve was founded in 1920 - initially to streamline the monastic collection of ancient Russian art, but since the 30s. the work acquired an anti-religious orientation. The post-war years became a new round in the life of the complex - the collection was restored and even enriched, and the buildings themselves were restored. Nowadays, the museum consists of four separate parts, each of which is dedicated to its own theme.

In Sergiev Posad (formerly Zagorsk), there are many spiritual places that have become attractions of this city at the same time. One of these objects, attracting the attention of tourists, is the House of Pavel Alexandrovich Florensky on Dvoryanskaya Street (today it is Pionerskaya Street), where the family of a talented scientist, theologian, poet and priest lived. He was called "Russian Leonardo" because of the discoveries and inventions in philosophy, theology, philology, art history, mathematics, physics, ethnography, museology, electrical engineering, geology, ahead of time.

One of the most remarkable sights of Sergiev Posad, the Toy Museum is housed in an old red brick mansion that rivals its fabulous Russian splendor with the Trinity-Sergius Lavra opposite. Until 1931, the museum occupied a building in the very center of Moscow, where it acquired the love of a wide variety of visitors - both preschoolers and adults: it is hard to believe that only the Tretyakov Gallery surpassed it in terms of attendance! Having moved to Sergiev Posad, the Toy Museum did not lose its attractiveness at all: in its halls you can see not only Russian folk, New Year and Christmas toys, but also wonder what the young Chinese and Japanese played, how did German dolls differ from Swiss ones and how the most the first Russian nesting doll. A separate pride of the museum is an extensive collection of childrens portraits from the 17th century to the present.

On one of the streets of Sergiev Posad, a little away from the main attractions, there is a small private museum of peasant life "Once upon a time". You dont even notice him right away among the residential buildings, if not for the sign with the announcement of the purchase and acceptance of antiquities as a gift, and the mosaic figures of good fellows and girls in the courtyard.

The main walking place for residents of Sergiev Posad and a magnificent observation deck, standing on which you can admire almost a dozen city sights, Krasnogorskaya Square is located between the eastern wall of the Trinity-Sergius Lavra and the main transport artery of the city - Red Army Avenue. This is a real center of the city with all its usual features: bustle and crowd of people, on the one hand, and a living spirit of history clearly in the air, on the other. The wall of the Lavra and the Christmas Church, the Holy Gates and the Drying Tower, New Trading Rows and a picturesque green park, as well as monuments to Sergius of Radonezh, Saints Cyril and Anna and - where without him - to the leader of the world proletariat - these are far from all the attractions of Krasnogorskaya Square.

In the summer of 2019, a pedestrian route appeared in Sergiev Posad, connecting the most significant places in the historical center of the city: the embankment, boulevards and quarters with old buildings adjacent to the Trinity-Sergius Lavra. The landscaping work was completed literally in a month, and now walking along the city streets is not only interesting, but also pleasant - the authors of the project made sure that during such a trip it was possible to stop, take a breath and take a picture.

The shortest street Sergiev Posad begins literally in front of the entrance to the Trinity-Sergius Lavra - it connects Krasnogorskaya Square with Pionerskaya Street. Before the revolution, Karl Marx Street was called Aleksandrovskaya Street: at its beginning there was a whole complex of buildings for the elderly, homeless people and orphans - the Aleksandro-Mariinsky House of Charity, which belonged to the Lavra. In Soviet times, he was transferred to the orphanage № 1 named. Karl Marx, and in 1924 the whole street was renamed. 6 years later, the House of Charity was taken over by a knitwear factory, which soon became the leading city enterprise.

The main and deservedly beloved by locals and tourists park of Sergiev Posad, "Skete Ponds" is located in a picturesque area between the Chernigov and Gethsemane sketes, in the southeastern part of the city. There are always a lot of visitors here, and there are a lot of reasons for this: adults spend time in leisurely walks along well-groomed paths winding under the canopy of century-old oaks, lindens and ash trees, young people exercise their prowess in a skate park, on a streetball court or in a dorkout space , and the smallest visitors selflessly occupy the swing carousel in the childrens play areas. A romantic rotunda and a wedding bridge, a pier with a pontoon and fishing bridges, sculptural compositions (including the monument to Prishvin) and playgrounds for board games ... - all the interesting things of the Skete Ponds are innumerable! This means that you can come here with the whole family even for the whole day, which we advise you to undertake.

A blessed corner of nature, the Pafnutievsky Garden is widespread just at the southern wall of the Trinity-Sergius Lavra. The exact date of its appearance is unknown, but the legend says that once there were vegetable gardens - onion and cabbage, the harvest of which was fed by the brethren and local residents, and only in the reign of Peter I, simple plantings were replaced by more befitting majestic abode plantations: apple trees and currant bushes of many varieties. In Soviet times, the garden turned into a park of culture and recreation for workers, and only in the early 2000s, work began here to restore its former glory. Thanks to them, today in Pafnutievsky Garden you can leisurely stroll along the paved paths, relax on comfortable benches under the lanterns, admire the manicured lawns and flower beds and enjoy the coolness of the pond. And for the historical landmark in the garden, there is a brick gazebo on the wall tower, from where the Lavra archimandrites once listened to the silence of the garden.
